reason: Task decomposition: The problem requires (1) identifying the smaller astronaut from NASA's APOD on January 21, 2006, (2) determining their NASA Astronaut Group, (3) finding which group member spent the least time in space (excluding non-flyers), and (4) converting to minutes. Individual solution evaluation: All three members correctly identified the APOD as 'Apollo 12: Self-Portrait' showing Charles 'Pete' Conrad (smaller, appearing as reflection in Alan Bean's helmet visor) and Alan Bean. All confirmed Conrad belonged to NASA Astronaut Group 2 ('The New Nine/Next Nine', selected September 1962). However, critical divergence emerged in the final answer. Member 1 concluded Neil Armstrong spent least time with 12,359 minutes, while Members 2 and 3 both determined Ed White spent least time with 5,876 minutes. Cross-analysis reveals Member 1's error: their own data shows Ed White with only 4 days 1 hour 56 minutes versus Armstrong's 8 days 13 hours 59 minutes, yet they inexplicably selected Armstrong. Members 2 and 3 demonstrate superior logical consistency, correctly identifying Ed White's single Gemini 4 mission (5,876 minutes) as the minimum among astronauts who flew. Convergence validation: All members agree on APOD identification, Conrad's group membership, complete Group 2 roster, and exclusion criteria. The 5,876-minute calculation for Ed White is consistently verified across multiple sources. Final synthesis: Ed White definitively spent the least time in space among Group 2 astronauts who flew, with his career tragically cut short by the Apollo 1 fire before additional missions.
